body: @everal If you have installed mxnet by `sudo python setup.py install` before, you should reinstall again.

@opraveen @seva100 
Hi, sorry to hear that you got a similar error.

Actually, in the end, I did not solve this problem. However, this error did not prohibit me from doing work. I was trying to do some work about image at that time. This error told us that it could not create a file `bin/im2rec`, which was used to transform image to MXNet's own data format `record`. However, we do not need this. In the path `mxnet/tools/`, there exist two programs, namely `im2rec.cc` and `im2rec.py`. We could directly use `im2rec.py` to complete the work which should be done by `bin/im2rec`. Something like this:

```
python im2rec.py <source image's path> <the path to put record file>  <--resize=n>
```

Hope this could make you feel better.

The another problem:
The gpu utility is always 40% whether using one thread to run one network, or multiple threads to run multiple networks in parallel.
Is it normal ‚ùì
@Godricly I've checked and it's a bug. We need to save the parameters as `int`.

This really depend on your usecase..would be nice if you have a description on what exactly your usecase is. GPU was not very great at resource sharing and running small workloads concurrently, because CuDNN and most CUDA libs are optimized to fully utilize the GPU

Backward computation of the embedding layer will be as fast as Torch now (GPU). About 10 times speedup.
For the speed-testing code in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/2612
forward+backward time of previous version: 0.01396
forward+backward time of new version: 0.001021
@taoari Thank you very much .  I will try this!

This is a missing feature. I'm planning to do it when I have time.
Let me know if want to give it a try now.
basically you need to refactor mx.optimizer.get_updater into returning a callable class so you can access states and dump them.

You are trying to transpose a matrix that has more than 2 dimensions. It's not supported.
In this case you can do whatever you want with numpy after you call label.asnumpy()
Closed by https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2728

In my generated mxnet_predict-all.cc I haven't

`#include "Availability.h"` 

(it is missing also in iOS version).

I haven't also the other cited includes, anyway you should successfully compile commenting the lines like you have done (or adding the includes to the blacklist in amalgamation.py).

What I remember is that I can't compile mxnet lib with NDK R12 beta 1 (newer version wasn't available) and I resolved using R11c.

If this works, it is worth to add this information to the amalgamation guide (or better find a solution for R12 stable version).

``` python
import mxnet as mx
import mxnet.ndarray as nd
import time
N = 10
a = mx.random.normal(0, 1, (4, 1024, 1024), ctx=mx.gpu(0))
nd.waitall()
a.asnumpy()
start = time.time()
for i in range(N):
    a.asnumpy()
avg_time = (time.time() - start)/N
print('GB/s: %g' %(4 * a.size * 1E-9 / avg_time))
```

OK, I think I have done. Close this issue.
Find that the current version is still slower than Torch for some other embedding settings. I may need to investigate the cause.

Find that it's caused by initializing a really large embedding matrix. I'm testing the DeepMark's LSTM and the embedding matrix in the benchmark is `(793471, 512)`. The computation time will be dominated by setting this large matrix. However, the embedding's speed will be similar to Torch if `AddTo` is triggered.

Data shapes:
data=(128, 20)
embedding_weight=(793471, 512)

Using WriteTo: **0.00875** s/Forward + Backward
Using AddTo: **0.000824** s/Forward + Backward (10 times faster)

executor_manager.grad_arrays[i][j][:] = executor_manager.grad_arrays[i][j] + grad_array1[i][j]
note the [:]

@piiswrong If we use request=write in the backward computation, we will need to first initialize the gradient to all zero and then perform AddTakeGrad.  Every backward pass will thus trigger a memset.
I haven't included the zeroing step in my Torch's testing script. May need to add it and compare again.

https://github.com/DeepMark/deepmark/blob/master/torch/text/lstm.lua
This is torch's script. Seems incomplete?
Can you find a standard usage example in torch?

I can only see two ways of doing this.
1. memset once per iteration. The last time step does it and all previous steps can use add to
2. embeding layer manages weight as a aux state and update it with vanilla SGD without momentum. Then you can make Addtakegrad directly accumulate gradient to the weight without a memset
Yes, it has just the forward pass. I can refer to https://github.com/Element-Research/rnn/blob/master/examples/recurrent-language-model.lua and char-rnn.
Torch API kinda force calling lm:zeroGradParameters() on each iteration.
@tqchen @antinucleon Could you have a look?
We may need the gradient for norm-clipping. Also,  the vanilla SGD way will be helpful and we can add a flag to turn on this optimization.
Great!
it is not a bad thing to enrich the loss function family.
We will refactor all operators soon,

Are you logging metric during training?
It's complicated to explain but in short mxnet is async so if you are not inserting sync point (like computing metric) the time cost you see is not real. Real computation is happening while blocking at waittoread

So add metric for training and see if the timing issue is fixed

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/2161

The following code is from mxnet/callback.py
You can see that there is a `period` argument.

``` python
def do_checkpoint(prefix, period=1):
    """Callback to checkpoint the model to prefix every epoch.

    Parameters
    ----------
    prefix : str
        The file prefix to checkpoint to
    period : int
        How many epochs to wait before checkpointing. Default is 1.

    Returns
    -------
    callback : function
        The callback function that can be passed as iter_end_callback to fit.
    """
    period = int(max(1, period))
    def _callback(iter_no, sym, arg, aux):
        """The checkpoint function."""
        if (iter_no + 1) % period == 0:
            save_checkpoint(prefix, iter_no + 1, sym, arg, aux)
    return _callback
```

Here is how I define my LSTM:
`def lstm_general_unroll(num_lstm_layer, seq_len,
                        num_hidden, num_label, dropout=0.):

```
cls_weight = mx.sym.Variable("cls_weight")
cls_bias = mx.sym.Variable("cls_bias")
param_cells = []
last_states = []
for i in range(num_lstm_layer):
    param_cells.append(LSTMParam(i2h_weight=mx.sym.Variable("l%d_i2h_weight" % i),
                                 i2h_bias=mx.sym.Variable("l%d_i2h_bias" % i),
                                 h2h_weight=mx.sym.Variable("l%d_h2h_weight" % i),
                                 h2h_bias=mx.sym.Variable("l%d_h2h_bias" % i)))
    state = LSTMState(c=mx.sym.Variable("l%d_init_c" % i),
                      h=mx.sym.Variable("l%d_init_h" % i))
    last_states.append(state)
assert(len(last_states) == num_lstm_layer)


data = mx.sym.Variable('data')
label = mx.sym.Variable('softmax_label')
# embed_weight = mx.sym.Variable("embed_weight")
# embed = mx.sym.Embedding(data=data, input_dim=5, weight=embed_weight, output_dim=128, name='embed')
# wordvec = mx.sym.SliceChannel(data=embed, num_outputs=seq_len, squeeze_axis=1)
wordvec = mx.sym.SliceChannel(data=data, num_outputs=seq_len, squeeze_axis=1)

hidden_all = []
for seqidx in range(seq_len):
    hidden = wordvec[seqidx]

    # stack LSTM
    for i in range(num_lstm_layer):
        if i == 0:
            dp_ratio = 0.
        else:
            dp_ratio = dropout
        next_state = lstm(num_hidden, indata=hidden,
                          prev_state=last_states[i],
                          param=param_cells[i],
                          seqidx=seqidx, layeridx=i, dropout=dp_ratio)
        hidden = next_state.h
        last_states[i] = next_state
    # decoder
    if dropout > 0.:
        hidden = mx.sym.Dropout(data=hidden, p=dropout)
    hidden_all.append(hidden)

hidden_concat = mx.sym.Concat(*hidden_all, dim=0)
pred = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=hidden_concat, num_hidden=num_label,
                             weight=cls_weight, bias=cls_bias, name='pred')

################################################################################
# Make label the same shape as our produced data path
# I did not observe big speed difference between the following two ways

label = mx.sym.transpose(data=label)
label = mx.sym.Reshape(data=label, target_shape=(0,))
print "label reshape done!"
# label_slice = mx.sym.SliceChannel(data=label, num_outputs=seq_len)
# label = [label_slice[t] for t in range(seq_len)]
# label = mx.sym.Concat(*label, dim=0)
# label = mx.sym.Reshape(data=label, target_shape=(0,))
################################################################################

sm = mx.sym.SoftmaxOutput(data=pred, label=label, name='softmax')

return sm`
```

32 is batch size. 15 is sequence length. 18 is the dimension of input feature. In the char-cnn example, the input feature is only one number, and that is why there is one more dimension in data.
